images.description:
Aurangabad

Ajanta and Ellora caves

November, 2019


For Thanksgiving 2019, we traveled to Aurangabad.


It's a small city near Mumbai, the site of a bunch of historical ruins.  


The Ajanta Caves and the Ellora Caves are the headliner attractions.  But there's an impressive medieval fort nearby, and another Taj Mahal too.

Ajanta Caves


A series of about 30 buddhist temples and monasteries carved into the cliff face.  None of the caves are natural, they're all dug by hand.

Bibi Ka Maqbara


Officially known as Bibi Ka Maqbara, but more usually referred to as the "Baby Taj."

Devagiri Fort 


It's is actually a fortified town-size area, with successive rings of curtain walls and moats (and sheer cliff faces).  In the top left you can see the Command Center.

Ellora Caves 


These caves are strung along the base of a basalt outcrop.  The site has Buddhist, Hindu and Jain collections of temples.  


Shown here is the biggest temple -- the main Hindu site.  It's not really a cave but a whole multi-floor temple, carved out of the mountain.

Day One


We visited the Ajanta Caves.  They're curved in a horse shoe around a canyon river. The setting kept the caves effectively hidden.


For some reason, Buddhist monks abandoned the caves about 700 AD. The site received little attention until 1819 when a British Captain, John Smith, encountered them on a hunting trip. 


Now they're a UNESCO World Heritage site.
Waiting our turn to get into Cave 19.
Cave 19 map (thanks wikipedia)
In Cave 1, they got this cool four-deer-with-one-head carving at the top of a pillar.

Wall paintings are a big deal at Ajanta.  Because the place was mostly abandoned from 700AD to 1800AD, many paintings survive.


To some approximation of "survive."

In the past 50 years, there's been a ton of scholarship based at Ajanta.  The paintings and the legends, stories of Buddha have been connected.  


At first, any given painting looks almost like a collage, or a "Where's Waldo for Buddha."  Except that Buddha is like, everywhere.  Every third or fourth person is, again, another Buddha.


But the paintings tell a collage-like story, describe a specific parable or legend from Buddha's life.

We heard a ton of stories about the paintings.  Good stuff.  


Usually, Sarah actually listened to the guide and Matt wandered off to take pictures.
At the innermost wall of each temple, there's a nice big Buddha presiding.
In this map the Final Boss Buddha is at the top, and the cliff-side entrance at the bottom.
Madras style.
Some of the temples are modest.  More like a cliff-side condo than a real monastery.

Along this wall there are seven, or eight buddhas.  Not sure.  It's always seven, or eight, or a thousand.


Historically, (mythopoetically speaking) there have been seven buddhas.  The one we know is #7, who came as a lowly priest.


Buddha #8 will come 5000 years after #7, and he will come as a king.  To judge, I assume, the living and the dead.
Bodiless Bodhisattva

Buddhas and carved columns.


But if you don't like buddhas and carved columns, you might give this place a miss.

Buddha with the hand reaching down is somewhat less common than other iconic poses.  It indicates a kind of doubt?  


The Buddha is surrounded by demons and sexy ladies, trying to pull him from the path.
Caves 9, 10 and 11.
In cave 10 they use Sumo guys to help hold up the ceiling.
These ceiling mandalas are in pretty good shape.
Sometimes buddhas collect in the corner and whisper.  Did you SEE what Rama Krishna was WEARING?
Elephant guards the stairs
Buddhist cave monkey
Sarah gets tired of having her picture taken.

It's not everyone, but there's a healthy percent of locals who want photos with foreigners.  The savvy ones know that asking, "Can I get a selfie with you?" is usually a non-starter (even gracious tourists tire of the practice).


However, if you ask, "Can you take our group photo for us?" Then the tourist is more likely to say yes.  And THEN, when the tourist is engaged, you ask for the pal-with-the-foreigner selfie.
Goodbye, Ajanta Caves.

Day Two.


We visited The Other Taj Mahal.  Its official name is Bibi Ka Maqbara, and it was built by the last serious Mughal Emperor, Aurungzeb.


Arungzeb's mom is buried in the real Taj.  This one he built in memory of his wife, Dilras Banu Begum.

This Taj was built with less fabulous materials (less marble, more white plaster.  Less obsidian, more black basalt).  And these days it's generally in less perfect shape.


In the tower, you can see some prodigious bird's nests.
In this version of the Taj, you are allowed to take pictures inside the main structure.
Repairs underway
Goodbye, Other Taj.

Devagiri Fort.


After the Other Taj, we drove to the fort known as Daulatabad or Devagiri or Deogiri.  Anyway, it's a big fort.


The principal reason to build it here, besides sitting astride a major road, is that the building on the heights in the upper left of the photo is sitting on a mountain made of super-sheer clfifs.

There are several layers of wall and gate guarding what was once the city of Daulatabad.  Here we're at the outermost gate.


Daulatabad was a big deal.  In fact the Sultanate seat of power moved from Delhi to Daulatabad for a while, starting in 1327.  But seven years later, they decided to return the imperial center to Delhi.
There is no city left, but the Minar is still here.  Second tallest minar (70 meters) in India, trailing only the famous Qutub Minar in Delhi.
Big minar
There was a whole posse of minar monkeys, but they won't sit sill for pictures.

The Yadava Dynasty rulers dug the already steep mountain into sheer cliff faces.  They excavated downward to make a moat that ran all the way around the mountain.


Crocodiles, natch.  They kept crocodiles in the moat.
Finally, at the top.  Two hundred meters vertical, lots of steps.
This is a pretty good view of the fortified city walls.
Goodby, Devagiri Fort.

Finally, we made it to The Ellora Caves.


There are three collections of caves here -- Buddhist, Hindu and Jain.

Also featured: dusty trees. Aurangabad was egregiously dusty.

First stop - a quick bus ride out to the site of the Jain caves.  The whole site is only a few kilometers end to end.  


But we were tired.  So we took the bus.
The main Jain cavern.  Two stories, lots of light available from the wide portico.
A little side cavern in the Jain complex.

Notable.  This guy still has his trunk.


As a rule, the Muslims, when they captured an area with temples and carvings, knocked off noses and boobs, but especially elephant trunks.


Perhaps because the Jain caves were carved later, they missed a few centuries of depredation, and thus, an intact trunk.
Jain Goddess of Fertility
Jain God of Wealth
Done with the Jain temples, back to the bus.

Hindu Temple


The biggest cave excavation is in fact no longer a cave.  They dug this entire temple out of the basalt mountain face.
Some of the cliff overhangs feel terrifying.  As if they will fall any moment.

This elephant fared... poorly.


There were a fair amount of Western tourists, but we made up only 5% of the visitor population.
Tatas is one of the biggest corporations in India.
Sarah and the Elephants
Considering that most of the elephant carvings are pretty life-like.  What is going on here...?
So long, Hindu temple
Buddhist caves at Ellora
The Buddhist caves at Ellora began excavation roughly at the time the site Ajanta was abandoned.

The big round thing is a stupa.  Traditionally, a stupa doesn't need any ornament or carving.  It is meant to represent the Buddha.


Also traditionally, there are relics of the Buddha inside it (a leg bone, perhaps?  a teacup?)
Here's a carving showing stupas, each with its own Buddha inside.
Goodbye, Ellora
